topic.title: Insert Path Shared Buffer Features

body.p: The GCC Processor insertion Shared Packet Buffer holds all Packet Data Unit (PDU) after all Ethernet headers and FCS have been removed. The Shared Packet Buffer is sized for 12 active ODUC1 or OTU4 GCC Links, 327680 bytes. The buffer is broken up into 512 byte blocks; 640 total blocks available. The Shared Packet Buffer fills one packet at a time and the GCC interface requires two bytes at a time for each GCC Link. A dropped packet interrupt occurs if there are not enough blocks for a full sized HDLC PDU (1968 bytes) as a new SOP arrives. This equates to four 512-byte blocks. A 32-bit dropped packet count (saturates at 0x80000000) is available.

The Shared Packet buffer output can support unicast (i.e each packet is destined to 1 GCC link) or multicast (i.e. each packet is destined to multiple GCC links). Multicast limit is upto 32 unique GCC links. GCC link to link mapping number is configured by Software. For multicast multiple GCC links will have the same link mapping number configuration. The Hardware will do the appropriate routing of incoming link mapping number to GCC link based on this configuration.

Firmware manages the block descriptors for unicast and multicast every 200 Âµs. Firmware writes a list of available blocks to an Empty FIFO which are used in order as each HDLC PDU arrives from the Ethernet interface. The used packet descriptors are written to a FIFO available to firmware which reads the descriptor and writes the descriptor to channelized queues. The descriptor is written to multiple queues in the case the Group Number is multicast to many GCC Links. A Group Number may multicast from 1:N where N = 1 to 32. Each queue is associated to a GCC Link and space for 32 descriptors are assigned to the queue per the link's ODU2 rate multiple. Completed descriptors from the queue are written to a Freed FIFO. Firmware reads the Freed FIFO and determines when the blocks are free. When free, the block number is written back into the Empty FIFO. HDLC processing is performed after the packet data is read from the buffer.
